CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 14, 1951, pg. 1, reads: "Fire Damages Crawford Grill One - A four [illegible]... undetermined origin almost completely destroyed... Greenlee's nationally known Crawford Grill...early Sunday morning, causing damage estimated... at $5,000 but by contractors at approximately... Located along Pittsburgh's 'Deep Wylie'... that begins at a church and ends in a jail' - the... and hotel, owned and operated by the well-known sportsman and baseball promoter, suffered damage to its first-floor bar, grill and elaborate Continental Room and Rumpus Room and hotel rooms on the second and third floors. Grill management hopes to have part, if not all, of it renovated and ready for re-opening by July 18, in time for the Charles-Walcott title fight... Inset, the impressive facade of the famous joy spot prior to the fire. - Jones and Harris Photos."
TitMainTitle: Three men, possibly including William Reed on right, standing outside of Crawford Grill No. 1, with sign in window inscribed "The restaurant is open Sundays," 1401 Wylie Avenue and Townsend Street, Hill District
